title: First-year Seminar
description: The First-year Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. First-year seminars can be offered in all campus departments and undergraduate colleges, and topics vary from quarter to quarter.

title: Greek Seminar
description: Readings in Greek covering specific topics in ancient Greek literature, philosophy, history, and religion. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

title: Latin Seminar
description: Readings in Latin covering specific topics in ancient Latin literature, philosophy, history, and religion. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

title: Early Christianity
description: This course examines the emergence, growth, and development of Christianity in its first centuries. The class explores issues of community, doctrine, and practice; inter-religious and intra-religious tension and conflict; and cultural continuity and change.

title: Classical Diversities
description: This course explores the questions of race and gender in the classical world, together with their impact on the study of the classics in the making of American identity.

title: World Wisdom Traditions
description: This online course explores wisdom traditions of the premodern world, examining formative ideas on the art of living well and contrasting worldwide teachings on what it means to be human, one's obligations to others, and the ideal relationship with the natural world.

title: Mythologies of the Ancient Mediterranean
description: This course examines the diverse literary, historical, and religious aspects of ancient Mediterranean myths. Focus may change from specific regions like Greece, Egypt, or Mesopotamia to a comparative view across multiple cultures, exploring their connections within and beyond the Mediterranean world. May be taken for credit up to two times as topics vary.

title: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study on a topic not generally included in the regular curriculum. Student must make arrangements with individual faculty members. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.

title: Independent Study
description: Independent study on a topic not generally included in the regular curriculum. Student must make arrangements with individual faculty members. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
